) Mission. The mission of the Office of Fraud Enforcement (OFE) is to compliance through strengthening the IRS’ response to fraud and mitigating emerging threats. This includes: • Improving fraud detection and development to address areas of high fraud/risk noncompliance. • Cultivating internal and external partnerships to identify new treatment streams to enhance enforcement. • Pursuing civil fraud penalties and recommending criminal cases that lead to prosecutions, where appropriate. (

) The OFE builds strong internal and external partnerships and serves as the primary civil liaison to IRS-Criminal Investigation. By supporting cases out the life cycle and through full consideration of available treatments, OFE facilitates optimal disposition of cases with civil or criminal fraud potential. (
) Purpose. This IRM section describes OFE procedures for researching, oping, and processing emerging threats to the tax system. (
) Audience. This handbook is for all IRS employees. (
) Policy Owner. Director, Office of Fraud Enforcement, Small Business Self Employed (SB/SE) Division. (
) Program Owner. Office of Fraud Enforcement. (

An ETT is processed when it has been reviewed and Each ETT is assessed using the Threat Assessment the following characteristics: a. Number of taxpayers impacted, b. Sufficiency of information provided, c. Relationship to existing lead(s), d. Consistency with EMT objectives, and e. EMT resource availability.

A viable ETT has multiple taxpayers, sufficient information, is not related to an existing lead, meets the deﬁnition of an ETT as deﬁned in IRM 25.1.15.1.6, Terms, and EMT has the resources available to address it.
Risked ETTs require EMT management review and approval. Approval is based on multiple factors, including risk score and available resources.

) The EMT C
maintains a record of emerging tax threats received and the status of the threats. Statuses include the following: a. Received: A new submission to the EMT C

b. Follow-up: A request for additional information is needed. c. Active: The period of assessment, public research, and risk. d. Selected: Approved for development into a lead. e. Closed: Tabled for a future date. (

) The LTR maintains a record of leads received and the status of the leads. Statuses includes the following: a. Active: OFE program manager approved, development and research in progress. b. Archived: Leads in closed status for at least one year. c. Completed: Leads researched, developed, recommended and/or d. On Hold: Inactive due to lack of resources. (

) The Lead Library contains the lead data. Approved and developed leads are stored in separately identiﬁable folders. Lead data includes the following mandatory documents: a. Research Action Plan (RAP) b. OFE program manager approval of ETT for development into a lead c. Risk Analysis d. Supporting documents, research, and analyses e. Final document (summary, conclusion, recommendation) (
